column1: Arcueil (French: [aʁkœj] (listen)) is a commune in the Val-de-Marne department in the southern suburbs of Paris
column2: France. It is located 5.3 km (3.3 mi) from the center of Paris.

column1: The name Arcueil was recorded for the first time in 1119 as Arcoloï
column2: and later in the 12th century as Arcoïalum
column3: meaning "place of the arches" (Latin radical arcus
column9: in reference to the Roman aqueduct carrying water to the Roman city of Lutetia (modern Paris). Still standing
column10: the arches of the Roman aqueduct are still visible since the Middle Ages
column11: crossing the Bièvre River valley near Arcueil.

column1: Between 1613 and 1624 a bridge-aqueduct over 1300 ft. long was constructed to convey water from the spring of Rungis
column3: across the Bièvre river to the Luxembourg Palace in Paris. Between 1868 and 1872 another aqueduct
column5: was superimposed above that of the 17th century
column6: forming part of the system conveying water from the river Vanne to Paris.The commune of Arcueil was officially renamed Arcueil-Cachan in 1894
column7: after the hamlet of Cachan located within the commune. On 26 December 1922
column8: Cachan seceded from the commune of Arcueil-Cachan and became a commune in its own right. The reduced commune of Arcueil-Cachan was renamed simply Arcueil.

column1: Arcueil is served by two stations on Paris RER line B: Laplace and Arcueil – Cachan.
